ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Kristin Morico is amazing. She's brilliant and nice and brings you free dinner.
It would have been better for a bit more structure - the instructor knows a lot but tends to jump around and be all over the places during the class.

Each lecture of this course was basically like a Q&A with the professor about her professional experience and with an overarching theme (e.g. career development/HR, communicating effectively, etc.). Lectures were not clearly organized or outlined; the setting was extremely informal. I think most students liked that this course provided free dinner and for many hearing about the professor's professional experience was probably interesting. The professor is very likeable and personable. However, I got very little out of this course that will aid my intellectual / professional development.
Kris was an excellent and passionate lecturer. I very much enjoyed the course.
Morrico is a wonderful instructor, very open and engaging.

This was a very loosely structured class. Although it was interesting to hear about the professor's career path, there was no clear thread to each lecture. There was also little focus on either the theoretical background of the subject or practical skill acquisition.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The instructor very generously bought us dinner every time...It was a relaxed forum for learning and talking about the corporate world.
The rich personal experience the instructor could bring in to the class.
The best aspects of the course was how open and relaxed the overall environment was.
Kris' experience
A handful interesting stories about working in the private sector.
Kris' insights into the working world of environmental decisionmaking.
Speaking and exhanging with the teacher
Assigned readings

Kris is awesome and is so thrilled to be imparting her wisdom to us. She also brought two other women leaders to speak tothe class at the end and they were great as well. Good to meet such strong female leaders.
Conversing with a strong female professional in the field who was very responsive to student inquiries.
The best aspect of the course was hearing from a successful professional woman.
Gives students exposure to high level professionals in the corporate environmental health and safety field. Relatively light courseload; appropriate for a one credit class.

Kristin has some interesting life experiences and stories to share and the class discussion was relatively interesting. I really appreciated having dinner provided and it was a nice time of day to have this type of class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The subject material became very vague, with a lack of depth. And it turned out it was a course on Environment, Health, and Safety perspectives, not Env. Leadership as a whole.
See Q13
The course may benefit from a bit more structure or specific goals.
Much more content and substance.
Pretty much everything. The course and the lectures need more structure, and learning objectives have tobe made more clear.
It needs more focused topic for each class, clear objectives this course should achieve for students.

I think this class's description was misleading and the curriculum should be re-worked. This was primarily focused on corporate sustainability, not general "leadership". I come from a background in environmental consulting and was familiar with many of the experiences Kris shared about workplace dynamics. I would like to see this class turned into something that is focused on building tangible skills such as interviewing, managing employees, and company analysis. Kris has all these abilities but most of class turned into a storytelling session that tended to wander and get off topic as we all chimed in on similar experiences. I would have liked to see it more structured as a long-term TSM class. Kris is a great resource for FES students and I would have like to walk away with more tangible skills to show for the class.
Maybe a little more topical structure with each week's discussion.

If this class is designed to be a practicum on environmental leadership and management, it would be useful to more clearly focus on specific skills or leadership techniques. For example, if week 1 is focused on communication, the professor could (1) provide a brief theoretical background (or assign readings with this background), (2) give examples of her own communication style and when it was worked/not worked, and (3) provide a structured activity for students to apply/practice communication techniques.
Following a more structured syllabus would be helpful. Though class had a nice open discussion format.
The class discussions could be a bit more structured and stay on topic a bit more. It would be nice to have more time to do the group project.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Good class discussions which incorporated reading materials.
n/a

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Want more practical and professional courses like this.
This class was very relevant to my intended career in corporate sustainability.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It sounded vaguely useful.
Due to the course description, which was very different from the course.
I took this course in order to gain leadership experience from a professional in the environmental field.
I am interested in corporate environmental leadership, which is the field that the instructor works in. I wanted to hear more about Kristin's career and her work at GE.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I didn't really have expectations.
Yes.
Didn't really gain knowledge or skills. Would have been better suited to someone who has never had a job before and really needed to start from scratch (hiring, salaries, reviews, ethics...)
Yes.
Yes
not at all.
See Question 15. The class description did not match the actual class experience.
Expectations were met.
This course met most of my expectations, however, I wished that the class discussion was more structured and more engaging. Sometimes it was interesting, other times it was not.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Good presentation skills to be gained
It was fun and informative to put together our presentation.
The group work was among the most enjoyable I have ever taken part in. The project was small enough that each person carried their own weight and learned from others.
It was quick and dirty. Not too painful.
Advantages: more comprehensive understanding of the material learning from others. Disadvantages: having to meet during midterms around everyone's schedules.
Work group went smoothly
I enjoyed researching a company with other classmates. It was a good first time experience doing this sort of analysis and good practice forpresentations.
Learned from group members, and the ability to cover more depth and breadth with the final project.
Learned a lot about the environmental health and safety performance and public reporting efforts of a large multinational corporation.
The group work was a highlight of the class, but it would have been nice to have had more time to complete it.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It is a leisurely Thursday night credit. However, your time may be better spent on homework.
Do it! The free food every week is awesome too.
Find out if the class has been restructured at all since last year. Ask the TA?
This course is relevant primarily to those interested in the corporate sector, and/or if you're looking to learn about different career paths.
This course is valuable if you simply want exposure to a professional in the EH&S field. However if you are expecting to gain specific skills, this is likely not the course for you.
Geared towards those considering careers in corporate environmental scene, but lots of applicable leadership skills and information easily transferable to other sectors.

This is a nice class with a low workload, primarily discussion based. The class discussion can be hit or miss in terms of whether or not it's interesting and/ oruseful. The group project is interesting and can be one of the most valuable components of the class.
